description: Composed of dis- +‎ information, a calque of Russian дезинформа́ция (dezinformácija), a word coined by Joseph Stalin c. 1923 (see the Wikipedia article). Attested in this sense in English from 1939. A morphologically-identical "disinformation" occurred earlier as a simple synonym of misinformation. Doublet of dezinformatsiya, an unadapted borrowing from Russian.

entries.meaning: False information intentionally disseminated to deliberately confuse or mislead; intentional misinformation.
Fabricated or deliberately manipulated content.  Intentionally created conspiracy theories or rumors.

verbs.description: disinformation (third-person singular simple present disinformations, present participle disinformationing, simple past and past participle disinformationed)

examples: A country cannot disinformation its way out of fallen soldiers.
